title: A High-Tech Sports Bar on Wheels for Justin Moore
text:
Justin Moore, an Arkansas-based country music singer and songwriter, with the tour bus he calls Razorback in Louisville, Ky., before an August gig. The bus was manufactured by Prevost, and Mr. Moore designed the interior accents with his wife. Photo: William DeShazer for The Wall Street Journal

Justin Moore, 35, a country music singer and songwriter from Poyen, Ark., on his Razorback tour bus, as told to A.J. Baime.

When you start out in this business and you get the opportunity to travel by tour bus, you are at the mercy of whatever you can afford. Then, if things go your way, you can start to make your tour bus nicer. The Razorback bus is the second one that my wife and I have designed. I spend so much time on this bus, I wanted to make it feel more like home.

We have a lot of exposed brick in our house in Arkansas, so we put real exposed brick in the bus. I am an outdoors guy. I was raised hunting and fishing, so the bus has drawer handles made out of deer antlers. The handle on the inside of the main door is made out of a replica shotgun.

Photos: The Bus Is Its Own Show Country star Justin Moore shows off his beloved Razorback tour bus from a stop in Louisville, Ky. Singer-songwriter Justin Moore on the tour bus he calls Razorback. He wrote his new single, ‘The Ones That Didn’t Make It Back Home,’ on the bus with the guitar pictured. William DeShazer for The Wall Street Journal 1 of 10 • • • • • 1 of 10 Show Caption Singer-songwriter Justin Moore on the tour bus he calls Razorback. He wrote his new single, ‘The Ones That Didn’t Make It Back Home,’ on the bus with the guitar pictured. William DeShazer for The Wall Street Journal On the road, I have two tour managers who sleep in bunks, and I have a bedroom in back with a full-size bed and a shower. There is even a walk-in closet. (I’m short, so it’s a walk-in closet for me.) I keep a guitar in the bedroom and when I have an idea, I grab it and record on my cellphone. In fact, my current single—“The Ones That Didn’t Make It Back Home”—I wrote on the bus. There are also a few TVs—17 of them, actually. When you grow up in the South, college sports are a huge deal, because many of the Southern states do not have professional teams. We watch a lot of games on the bus, and during football season when the weather cools off, we put games on two TVs outside the bus. During March Madness, we can put games on different TVs. Why do I call the bus Razorback? I live on the same land in Arkansas where I grew up, in a town of about 300. My wife and I have built a great relationship with the University of Arkansas, and the school gave us the OK to put the Arkansas Razorback logo huge across the back of the bus. I have the team colors as the paint scheme. This coming Saturday, we will be on the road in Iowa and the Razorbacks will be playing Ole Miss. This is a huge football rivalry, and my crew and I will be watching on the bus. It’s not home, but it sure beats airports and airplanes. Write to A.J.
